positive.review:
This is the best tower defense game I've played so far, and like the previous Bloons Tower Defense games, it is incredibly fun and definitely one of the games where grinding can be fun to do. 

What's great about this game is, like the previous games, especially BTD5, you get a variety of everything, which includes the towers, the upgrades for them, the maps, the enemies, and finally the difficulties for all of them. There are maps that are either easy or maps that can be very difficult to beat, depending on the difficulty chosen, but it is all part of the fun of this game.

This is definitely a must game to buy for any tower defense and strategy players, and not to mention, it has co-op you can play with either random people or friends, which is even more fun.

P.S: You guys should add Extreme Difficulty maps just like in BTD4 & 5 <3

This isn't a tower defense game, it's THE tower defense game. Insane value for the cheap price and still gets a fairly large update every 2-3 months. I wish Plants VS Zombies had ended up like the Bloons series instead of becoming a cheap sellout joke of a franchise that hasn't made a decent game since the very first one. BTD6 is what happens when the same developer stays consistently good for over 15 years straight without selling their soul to a huge company. This is definitely a great comfort game to chill out and play but you can also go full min/max and go for a 7 hour hardcore round with friends. The art style looks somewhat kiddish but the gameplay can get unbelievably challenging depending on what modes/events you're playing. I think this is really a game for everyone and I hope ninja kiwi stays passionate about this franchise. Also a fun fact: I have never in my hundreds of hours of playing BTD6 (I have many more hours on mobile) encountered a single bug or glitch, which I'm not sure I can say for any other game out there
i have a really bad addiction to bloons td 6, it is crippling and alienating me from my family and friends. absolutely amazing game 100% reccomend :steamhappy:

[h1] 8.5/10 [/h1]

It may look dumb for an adult to be playing this game, but behind the kid-level graphics and funny noises, is a lot of strategic and tactical depth. 
Pros:
Lots of replayability
Easy to just sit back and relax.
Plenty of options to increase difficulty to test your mettle
Developers are still actively updating the game
The best Tower Defense style game I've ever played.
Cons:
Regardless of how fast your computer is, if you want to play a multi-hour game (playing hundreds of rounds), your frame rate will eventually drop to two FPS.
Co-op play tends to de-synch just enough to become a hassle for co-op play.

Unfortunately, tower defense games have been on a decline; itâ€™s a game genre thatâ€™s considered old or â€œa mobile game,â€ and honestly, itâ€™s true.

This genre is very old and was built on limitations, this game though, itâ€™s different.

The general simplicity of â€œmonkey pop bloonâ€ and â€œbig and cool monkey pop big bloonâ€ is very inviting and easy to understand, yet the game can get very difficult and requires great understanding and patience. The difficulty range is incredible, if youâ€™re a chill gamer, you can play an easy relaxing map, and if you are a hardcore gamer, there are much more difficult maps that will take you hours to figure out. And donâ€™t get me started on CHIMPSâ€¦

Did I mention the challenge/map editors? You can find thousands of custom-made challenges/maps that are very accessible through the game. Some of them will showcase something cool, others will teach you something about a specific tower, and some will take you days to figure out.

The amount of game types, upgrades, levels, tower combos, maps, and challenges is truly remarkable â€” easily the best and most complete tower defense game on the market, and itâ€™s piss cheap (on discount it's less than 2$)

OVERALL RATING: 8/10
Great game that is for everybody.

[h1]What is it?[/h1]

Bloons is a classic tower defense game where your sworn enemies areâ€¦ balloons. You stop the sinister rubber threat from reaching the end of a path by deploying an army of cute monkeys armed with everything from darts to literal orbital lasers. As rounds progress, the bloons get faster, tougher, and develop special properties. This forces you to combine tower types, manage resources, and make enough strategic decisions to qualify for a mid-level military consulting job.

[h1]The Good[/h1]

[b]Strategic Gameplay[/b]
Thereâ€™s a large variety of monkeys to choose from, each with unique upgrade paths that range from â€œreasonableâ€ to â€œDid we just invent monkey-powered thermonuclear warfare?â€ Advanced maps throw curveballs at you so you canâ€™t just run the same cookie-cutter strategy every game. A passive skill tree adds even more depth, just in case a hundred upgrade options werenâ€™t enough commitment for you.

[b]Replayability[/b]
There are so many maps, modes, challenges, and events that you could play this game for weeks and still go, â€œWait, what is that tower supposed to do?â€ And the devs add new content constantly: monkeys, maps, cosmetics, theyâ€™re in a long-term relationship with this game and it shows.

[b]The Vibe[/b]
Everything is aggressively cute. The monkeys? Adorable. The animations? Adorable. The bloons? Adorable but also evil. If you ever need a quick dose of wholesome serotonin to forget the horrors of adulthood, boot up Bloons and let the monkey army soothe your weary soul ðŸ’œ

[h1]The Bad[/h1]

[b]It's a Mobile Game[/b]
You can tell this game was designed for mobile first. The game occasionally tries to lure you into buying in-game currency, just a little nudge like â€œHey, wouldnâ€™t unlocking this hero instantly be nice?â€ 

But honestly, you donâ€™t have to buy anything. I havenâ€™t spent a single cent beyond the base game and a DLC that adds a rogue-like mode and I still ended up with more in-game currency than I knew what to do with. So while itâ€™s technically pay-to-progress, the grind is gentle and fairly balanced. And not buying anything also keeps the sense of progression intact.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

If you enjoy tower defense games, Bloons is a no-brainer. With tons of replayability, ongoing updates, and cross-progression between Steam and mobile itâ€™s the perfect game whether youâ€™re killing five minutes on the train or five hours avoiding your responsibilities at home. Itâ€™s charming, strategic and just the right amount of addictive.

[b]Bloons TD 6[/b] is an extensive, modern instalment in the Bloons Tower Defence series of strategy games, and as with the previous games in the series, the main objective of the game is to build and maintain a line of defence against approaching balloons, utilising monkeys of a range of classes with special abilities. The game, on top of its large collection of playable maps (and their additional game modes), also offers multiplayer features, encouraging team effort in building a successful defence.

The game keeps players engaged and coming back for more with daily challenges and global events. Players can also create and share their own challenge maps with others, allowing vast customisation options for players seeking for specific types of challenges. Though the content and mechanics of the game may be overwhelming to new players, the game is likely to eventually grow on them, if given enough time.

Honestly after 12 years of consistent playtime I can say with upmost certainty that this is one of the best video games to ever have been created. In 2014 my wife became so frustrated with my constant 'bloon-popping' that the stupid b*tch made us go to counseling. Lol. What a dumb b*tch. Anyways, after a few months of that, she came to the realization that I would never, ever, change - that Bloons Tower Defense had become the very thing I live for - what my body and spirit yearned for. Eventually, she wound up taking the kids to live with her mother in Vermont, who I was never quite fond of so it didn't bother me even slightly. Still, as I erect my technological terrors sometimes I hear the faint whispers of my *former* children, saying "daddy, daddy, where did you go?"... no matter! More bloons for me!! YUM YUMM!!

Deep, flexible tower-defense mechanics
The core loop is simple but strategic: place monkey â€œtowers,â€ pop â€œBloons,â€ earn cash, upgrade towers, defend longer waves. 

Thereâ€™s a wide variety of towers (monkeys with darts, magic, support, etc.), each with multiple upgrade paths â€” this gives many different approaches and play-styles. 
 
Endgame possibilities like â€œParagonâ€ upgrades (merging strong towers), and â€œHeroâ€ towers with unique abilities, add long-term strategic depth beyond basic tower upgrades. 
Plenty of content + replayability

The game offers dozens of maps and a wide variety of modes beyond standard waves: there's co-op, boss events, challenge modes, and even community-created content. 
 
There are â€œmeta-upgradesâ€ (sometimes called â€œMonkey Knowledgeâ€ or similar) â€” permanent or long-term upgrades, which reward continued play and experimentation. 
 
For many players, the mixture of casual-friendly visuals and deeper strategic mechanics hits a sweet spot: easy enough to start, but with enough complexity to stay interesting for many hours. 

The game uses 3D graphics with cartoonish, colorful, and clear visuals. Bloons, towers, and paths are easy to distinguish. 
The UI and controls (especially on PC / Steam / touch devices) are generally straightforward and make building/upgrading towers manageable even during hectic rounds. 
It supports both single-player and multiplayer (co-op for up to 4 players), so it works both as a solo game or with friends.

Pros: borderless windowed mode is default, charming soundtrack & art style, tutorial available, accessibility settings, an overwhelming amount of content & unlocks, speed-up button on the bottom right, hero towers that level up, multiple difficulty levels to choose from

Cons: no graphical settings, no pause button, no pause between rounds by default (you have to disable auto-start in the options menu), on the main menu the buttons on the left & right sides have no description, it is unclear what the bottom left buttons do for your towers, some menu buttons require a login account

Overall, I have spent 5 hours as of the writing of this review with this tower defense game. You can easily spend hundreds of hours playing this game.
Bloons TD 6 has my highest recommendation

Just one more round... Just one more medal... Just one map... Just one more unlock...

This game never ends. I have to stop.

Aside from being one of the most addictive games I've ever played, BTD6 is an inspired installment of the iconic Bloons Tower Defense series. Keeping with the tradition, this game features more towers, maps, gamemodes, and content than its predecessors. This makes it exciting to dive into, but here I am approaching 80 hours of playtime and I feel like I haven't yet explored half of what this game has to offer. I never tried the Odysseys, races, bosses, or any of the advanced or expert maps. I wanted to unlock all the tower upgrades, but I couldn't even do that. I am recommending this game because it is fun and well-made, but players should be aware that this game will do everything it can to consume you and your time. 

Caution aside and regrets notwithstanding, BTD6 is a great game that surpasses its predecessors. From the parts of the game I did experience, BTD6 impressed me as being one of the most balanced games in the series. No longer are there strong towers and weak towers--every tower can contribute to your defence. This, combined with having so many options for camo detection and MOAB destruction, gave me a sense of freedom that the previous games did not. Not only does this enable exploration, the large variety of game-modes encourages it. You are not locked in to just a couple of strategies--try new things and have fun! 

This game is not without its flaws, but as someone who has enjoyed watching the series evolve over the years, BTD6 blew me away. Nevertheless, its time to get on with my life.

Worst instalment of the Bloons TD series. The game is full of micro transactions and feels like one of those "free" mobile games that constantly want you to buy stuff, ported to PC. Including the "oh you got a message" symbol wanting you to sign up for an account. It also gets boring really fast. The multiplayer part of the game is just literally jank. Connections dropping is not uncommon, and then there is simply no way for somebody to rejoin. 
If you can pick it up for $2, get it. But for the normal price just stay away from it and grab Bloons TD5 instead.

This negative score comes wholly from the Co-op experience. The cooperative mode is buggy and unresponsive, its joining system and quitting system is buggy and effectively non-functional. The required multiplayer grinding is a painful and tedious experience that ruins what is otherwise an enjoyable experience. I look forward to the DLC as they seem to be wholly unique additions building on a solid gameplay format.

Directions
Step 1
Make the cannabutter, following the quantities listed above and my step-by-step guide linked in the Author Notes.

Step 2
Preheat the oven to 350Â°F (177Â°C) and line an 8-inch square pan with parchment in both directions.

Step 3
In a double boiler (or in the microwave in 10-second intervals), melt the cannabutter and dark chocolate. Remove the bowl from the heat, then add the molasses, vanilla, and salt.

Step 4
In a medium bowl, add the eggs and use a handheld mixer to blend on low speed until the eggs look frothy, about 1 minute. Slowly add the sugar while blending on low speed, then increase to medium speed to beat until lighter in color, thick and fluffy, 2 to 3 minutes.

Step 5
Sift or whisk the flour with the cocoa powder, then add to the chocolate butter mixture, using a rubber spatula to stir until the flour completely disappears, about 30 seconds. Fold in the sweetened eggs until the batter looks cohesive. Fold in the chopped nuts (if youâ€™re using them).

Step 6
Pour the batter into the pan, using the spatula to spread evenly from corner to corner, and place in the center of the oven. Bake for 25 minutes, until a glossy top forms and starts to crack. Keep an eye on the edges, they will firm up first. To check, insert a toothpick near the cornerâ€”it should have a few moist crumbs.

Step 7
Let cool on a wire rack for at least 15 minutes before cutting into 16 brownies. (If youâ€™d likeâ€”and if your pan isnâ€™t glassâ€”you can plunge the pan into cold water immediately out of the oven. The temperature shock achieves a chewy crust while maintaining the gooey center, a tip I learned from Eric Kim.)

Step 8
Store the brownies in an airtight container for up to a week. For longer storage, cut and freeze the brownies, then warm up in the microwave or oven before serving.

I would also recommend packing yourself a large bong.

over time they have piled on more and more microtransactions and it is clear that this is a mobile game in a steam game's clothing

when it was just monkey money, monkey knowledge and double cash mode (plus some other stuff that i doubt anyone ever touched) it was fine, but now that they're starting to lock powers and gamemodes behind having to pay up real money it feels scummier than ever. Especially when the roguelike dlc costs 75% the price of the base game, at least in my region (aus) while not adding much actual like, content. Suuuuuure you get randomised tower restrictions and randomised waves but is that really worth 75% the price of every other gamemode combined? Absolutely not. At least they didn't lock achievements behind it, that's something.

Look, don't charge me for a game AND do microtransactions.
It's a shame, because the gameplay loop is enjoyable.

the game is really fun but after you get used to the same old gameplay loop the only real fun is logging in to see how updates change the game, and upon doing so you remember that the game has terrible connection in multiplayer. and to make things worse, if you disconnect theres no way to connect to a game that was in progress even if youre friends with people still in it. which is annoying when you spent 30 minutes trying to see the new paragon and have to start over...

A charming tower defence game. Very enjoyable, with some interesting mechanics.

It's got a great review score overall because it's a decent game, but I'm not recommending it because of the microtransactions. It seems like every other button in the menu invites you to purchase game upgrades for real money, and I just don't agree with that in principle.

Better to get Defense Grid.
dude the game just fully reset my account...... I have almost 3 hours of playtime and got to about level 30+ but the game has just wiped all my data for no reason why!?!?!!!
150h played, did not backup all gone, does not sync with Steam automatically.

(Posting it as not recommended because Steam for some reason makes you pick "positive" or "negative" without an in-between option.)

pay to win/micro transactions. its possible to far in this game but the hours needed would take years and its not like there's much gameplay. I remember paying 5 bucks for the app games and having everything and not needing to pay for in game curency
awfully overpopulated with options/heroes/difficulties. A real hangover of choices. Though this is the real purpose of these games.. to kill your time.

What used to be a free-to-play flash game, is now a free-to-play mobile game, with morden-microtransactions and monetisation, while still bearing a $13 price tag.

I wouldn't mind grinding monkyes and upgrades for (an absurd) 80~ hours or so, before I could unlock them all, in the name of normal game progression. But it becomes extreamly tedious when you get contstantly get pestered with the opertunity to unlock everything instantly, by giving NinjaKiwi more money. The prefered method.

'I refuse!', I say. I will contuine to download c-tables.

terrible game the creators didnt add me even tho i asked nicely

Worst instalment of the Bloons TD series. The game is full of micro transactions and feels like one of those "free" mobile games that constantly want you to buy stuff, ported to PC. Including the "oh you got a message" symbol wanting you to sign up for an account. It also gets boring really fast. The multiplayer part of the game is just literally jank. Connections dropping is not uncommon, and then there is simply no way for somebody to rejoin. 
If you can pick it up for $2, get it. But for the normal price just stay away from it and grab Bloons TD5 instead.
I haven't used it but speed up mods are considered hacking. They should add a faster option. Besides there are too many micro-transactions.

Felt impossible to link an account.

When I had to get a new PC everything got wiped, I had my ID but that didn't help me anywhere.
Looks fun but the colors are burning my eyes.

Pretty basic and boring. Doesn't hold up as a good TD game in 2025.
